title: Latin cross
text:
A Latin cross or crux immissa is a type of <a href="cross">cross</a> in which the <a href="wikt%3Avertical">vertical</a> beam sticks above the <a href="wikt%3Acrossbeam">crossbeam</a>, with the three upper arms either equally long or with the vertical topmost arm shorter than the two horizontal arms, and always with a much longer bottom arm.
If displayed <a href="wikt%3Aupside%20down">upside down</a> it is called <a href="Cross%20of%20St.%20Peter">St. Peter's Cross</a>, because he was reputedly <a href="execution">executed</a> on this type of cross. When displayed sideways it is called <a href="Philip%20the%20Apostle">St. Philip</a>'s cross for the same reason.
Use in the United States.
In the United States, the Latin cross began as a <a href="Roman%20Catholic">Roman Catholic</a> <a href="emblem">emblem</a>, being vehemently contested as Satanic by various <a href="Protestant">Protestant</a> denominations in the 19th century, but has since become a universal symbol of <a href="Christianity">Christianity</a> and is now the main representation of the cross for Protestants, too.
Cruciform churches.
A Latin cross plan is a <a href="floor%20plan">floor plan</a> found in many <a href="Church%20%28building%29">churches</a> and <a href="cathedral">cathedral</a>s. When looked at from above or in <a href="plan%20view">plan view</a> it takes the shape of a Latin cross ("crux immissa"). Such <a href="cruciform">cruciform</a> churches were very common in the <a href="West">West</a> during the <a href="Romanesque%20architecture">Romanesque</a> period. The Latin cross plans have a <a href="nave">nave</a> with <a href="aisle">aisle</a>s or <a href="chapel">chapel</a>s, or both, and a <a href="transept">transept</a> that forms the arms of the cross. It also has at least one <a href="apse">apse</a> that traditionally faces <a href="east">east</a>. Many also have a <a href="narthex">narthex</a> at the entry.
